column4: Can someone lend me a hand with tune2fs? Even after telling it not to reserve blocks it still seems to be doing the same thing. 28 GB used on 2 TB without anything done to it
what command did you use
I've tried tune2fs -m 0 /dev/sdb1 and tune2fs -r 0 /dev/sdb1
mind if I link you to the forum thread?
http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=1982635
so your problem is that the reserved block count is zero, but the free blocks is less than the block count
I'm not sure. It still says 28 GB used in df -h. But yeah, free blocks is less than block counts
i wonder what running an fsck would do
I can give it a try I guess
fsco -a alright for this?
fsck from util-linux 2.20.1
when unmounted I see this:
df wont tell you anything when it is unmounted
im not sure. thats very strange.
should I perhaps repartition? Do you know if there's a way to select block size reserve space in parted or something
to be honest i would just leave it at 5%. if you actually start using more than 95% of the filesystem thats not good and you need to get more storage
so in some ways that 5% buffer is only preventing you from doing something you probably wouldn't want to do anyways
if its really empty you could just rerun mkfs with the correct options
that's what I'm looking at doing.
it helps prevent fragmentation. 28Gb may be bigger than necessary, but there is no guarantee that those 28GB will be contiguous so 5% isn't crazy
bandit5432 I ran  sudo mkfs.ext4 -m 0 /dev/sdb1
